Hon. George A. Isaacs, M.P., Minister of Labour' and National Service.Sir,We have the honour to present the following report on the 30th Sessionof the International Labour Conference.introduction. The 30th Session of the International Labour Conference was held in geneva from 19th June to 11th July, 1947.2. The delegates appointed to represent His Majesty's Government wereSir Guildhaume Myrddin-Evans, K.C.M.G., C.B., Deputy Secretary, Ministryof Labour and National Service, Chairman of the Governing Body of theInternational Labour Office, and Mr. G. R. A. Buckland, C.B., Under-Secretary, Ministry of Labour and National Service, together with Mr. E. A.Hitchman, Under-Secretary, Ministry of Labour and National Service, assubstitute delegate and adviser. Sir John Forbes Watson, K.C.M.G.,Director of the British Employers' Confederation, Member of the governing body of the International Labour Office, was appointed to represent theUnited Kingdom employers; and Sir Joseph Hallsworth, Member of theGeneral Council of the Trades Union Congress, General Secretary, Unionof Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers, Member of the Governing Bodyof the International Labour Office, was appointed to represent the UnitedKingdom workers. In addition, 12 advisers were appointed to the Govern-ment delegates, 8 advisers to the employers' delegate and 6 advisers to theworkers' delegate. The complete list of the delegation is given in Appendix I.3. The items on the Agenda of the Session- were :I. Report of the Director-General.II. Financial and Budgetary Questions.III. Minimum Standards of Social Policy in Dependent Territories.(provisions suitable for a Convention) (second discussion).IV. Organisation of Labour Inspection in Industrial and CommercialUndertakings (single discussion).V. Employment Service Organisation (first discussion).VI. Reports on the Application of Conventions (Article 22 of theConstitution).VII. Freedom of Association and Industrial Relations.4. The Et. Hon. George A. Isaacs, M.P., Minister of Labour and NationalService, and the Rt. Hon. Ness Edwards, M.P., Parliamentary Secretary,Ministry of Labour and National Service, visited and addressed the Confer-ence during the discussion of the Directors Report. Delegations from otherGovernments included the following Ministers : the Hon. E. J. Ward, M.P.,Minister of Transport and External Territories, Australia; Mr. Leon-EliTroclet, Minister of Labour and Social Welfare, and Mr. Henri Heyman.35069 a 2 Minister of State, Belgium; H.E. Zdravko Mitovsky, Minister of Social Affairs,Bulgaria; Mr. Shri Jagjivan Earn, then Member of Council in charge ofLabour, India; Mr. Gulzari Lai Nanda, Minister of Labour and Housing,Bombay Province, India; Mr. Amintore Fanfani, Minister of Labour, Italy;H.E. Andres Serra Rojas, Minister of Labour and Social Welfare, Mexico;H.B. Kazimierz Businek, Minister of Labour and Social Welfare, Poland.H.B. Sadi Irmak, Minister of Labour, Turkey, attended the Conference. the hon. C. C. Williams, Minister of Labour, Saskatchewan, accompanied theGovernment delegation of the Dominion of Canada.OPENING OF THE conference. The Conference was opened by the Chairman of the Governing Body,Sir Guildhaume Myrddin-Evans (His Majesty 's Government's representa-tive). In his formal opening speech Sir Guildhaume Myrddin-Evans, after giving an account of the main events affecting the Organisation since theconclusion of the previous Conference at Montreal in October 1946, went onto refer to the liberty of the person, "of all things in the world the mostprecious." He concluded with these words: " In this storm-wracked world of to-day my mind goes back to the wordsspoken by Lincoln at Gettysburg 84 years ago when, speaking of theAmerican nation, he said ' our fathers brought forth on this Continent anew nation, conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal.' I hope that our United States friends will notthink me presumptuous when I suggest that we can perhaps apply thosenoble words to the I.L.O. Be that as it may, just as Lincoln called uponbis countrymen in 1863, so to-day this Organisation, which is uniquelyequipped to further the cause of liberty, can, adapting Lincoln's words,call upon the peoples of the earth to resolve that the millions of ' dead ofthe last few years shall not have died in vain,' to resolve ' that this world,under God, shall have a new birth of freedom.' "ELECTION OF THE PRESIDENTS AND VICE-PBESIDENTS6. Mr. Carl Hambro, Government delegate of Norway, was unanimouslyelected President of the Conference. The Vice-Presidents elected wereMr. Carlos Raul Desmaras, Argentine Republic, for the Government group,Sir John Forbes Watson, United Kingdom, for the employers' group, andMr. Robert J. Watt, United States of America, for the workers' group.MEMBERSHIP OF THE ORGANISATION7. The Conference, by a Resolution adopted unanimously, readmittedAustria to membership of the Organisation. It was announced that thePhilippine Republic and El Salvador had indicated their intention of entering the Organisation under that provision of the Constitution which accordsmembership to any member of the United Nations. It was further announcedthat Yugoslavia had given the statutory two years' notice of its intentionto withdraw from the Organisation.CREDENTIALS8. Objections were presented concerning the appointment of the Workers'delegates and Workers' advisers of the Argentine Republic, Chile, Greece,India, Iran and Uruguay. These objections were rejected by the CredentialsCommittee. REPORT OF THE DIRECTOR-GENERAL(Item I of the Agenda)9. The Director-General's . Report contained a general study of world economic developments and described the activities of the InternationalLabour Organisation in the period since the 29th Session of the InternationalLabour Conference. Several plenary sittings of the Conference were occupiedT"with the discussion of this Report.10. In his speech on the Director-General's Report, the Rt. Hon. GeorgeA. Isaacs, M.P., Minister of Labour and National Service, stressed thesupreme importance of the International Labour Organisation:'' The International Labour Organisation,'' he said, "is a world-wideorganisation of nations and its strength is in its tripartite nature. the collaboration of Governments, employers and workers is essential if a successful solution is to be found for the economic ills of the world. Infact, it is the only way. There are, of course, many questions which employers' and workers' representatives must necessarily approach from different points of view, but it is only through the frank interchange ofopinion on the basis of equality that it is possible to frame policies whichare both practicable and capable of implementation on the basis of commonagreement."11. The Rt. Hon. Ness Edwards, M.P., devoted the major part of his speech to a description of the Government's policy on the employment of disabled persons, a subject in which the International Labour Organisation has taken a special interest. He also referred to the relations between the I.L.O. andthe United Nations and other international organisations in the following terms: "I should like," he said, "to congratulate the Director-General on an excellent Report.....If I refer specially to one feature of the Report the record of increasing co-operation with the United Nations and other international organisations it is because I believe that we cannot afford to miss the smallest chance of working together if we are to have any realhope of accomplishing the common tasks of banishing war and bringinghappiness, prosperity and freedom to all our peoples. The British Govern-ment, therefore, welcomes wholeheartedly this new development, whichhas followed the conclusion of the Agreement, with the United Nations."FINANCIAL AND BUDGETARY QUESTIONS(Item II of the Agenda)12. The Conference approved a net expenditure Budget for 1948 at SwissFrancs 18,942,983 compared with Swiss Francs 15,952,900 for 1947. As theresult of increased contributions from certain Members the number of unitsof contributions from the States Members of the Organisation will beincreased from 690 for 1947 to 784 in 1948. The United Kingdom contribu-tion remains at 108 units and the United Kingdom share of the net expendi-ture Budget is 13-8 per cent, in 1948 compared with 15-7 per cent, in 1947.After crediting the 1946 surplus, the net cash contribution to be made tothe Organisation by the United Kingdom will be Swiss Francs 2,318,553 in1948 compared with Swiss Francs 2,232,863 in 1947. MINIMUM STANDARDS Ol1 SOCIAL POLICY IN dependent territories(Item III of the Agenda)13. The work of the Conference oii conditions in dependent territoriesrepresented the final stage in discussions extending over three years. TheConference had, in the words of the Reporter of the Committee on this item,." passed from the stage of declaration to that of recommendation and now" )to that of the international convention." The Conference adopted a seriesof five Conventions dealing with the following subjects : social Policy in Non-Metropolitan Territories;The Right of Association and the Settlement of Labour Disputes in Non-Metropolitan Territories ;Labour Inspectorates in Non-Metropolitan Territories;The Application of International Labour Standards to Non-metropolitan territories; and the Maximum Length of Contracts of Employment of IndigenousWorkers.14. The Convention on Social Policy in Non-Metropolitan Territories covers a particularly wide field. In the words of Article 4 of the Convention " allpossible steps shall be taken by appropriate international, regional, national and territorial measures to promote improvement in such fields as publichealth, housing, nutrition, education, the welfare of children, the status ofwomen, conditions of employment, the remuneration of wage earners and independent producers, the protection of migrant workers, social security,standards of public' services and general production." Special provisionsrefer to the protection of the rights of migrant workers, the encouragement of collective bargaining for the purpose of establishing minimum wages and non-discrimination on grounds of race, colour, sex, belief, tribal associationor trade union affiliation.15. The question of non-discrimination on the grounds of sex gave rise to considerable discussion in the appropriate Committee of the Conference. Itwas originally proposed that a separate section of the Convention shouldbe devoted to provisions concerning women workers and that, in particular the section should provide that " laws and regulations covering women workers shall assure them equal treatment with men with due regard forsuch protection as is needed to safeguard maternity." The United KingdomGovernment member of the Committee submitted amendments to theproposed text, the effect of which was to make unnecessary a separatesection concerning women workers, a course which ultimately provedgenerally acceptable. The United Kingdom Government member also expressed the view that, as drafted, certain of the proposals relating toequality of treatment as between men and women workers were in conflictboth with certain International Labour Conventions and with the nationallegislation of many Member States concerning the protection of women,and, if adopted, would make the position of women worse than at present.Thus, a general requirement that there must be absolute equality as betweenmen and women workers in relation to the prohibition of employment inparticular occupations, industries or circumstances, would involve giving upthe prohibition of the employment of women underground or on night work.This view was accepted by the Committee and ultimately by the Conference,'and, on the proposal of the United Kingdom' Government representative, itwas provided in the final text of the Convention (Article 18 (4)) that the mprovisions in regard to;-non-discrimination "shall be without prejudice tosuch measures as the competent authority may think it necessary or desirable to take for the safeguarding of motherhood and for ensuring the health, safety and welfare of women workers."16. The question of '' equal treatment with men as ' regards remunera-tion " also arose in connexion with the suggested provisions relating to women workers. ' The United Kingdom Government member of the Com-mittee pointed out the difficulties to which such a provision might give rise.1 respect of the metropolitan territory, and proposed that the relevant pro-vision (Article 18 (1)) should refer to -the fixing of wage rates" according to the principle of equal pay for work of equal value in thesame operation and undertaking to the extent to which recognition of this principle is accorded in the metropolitan territory." This amendment also was accepted and formed part of the text ultimately adopted by the Con-fere nee.17. The Convention was adopted by 103 votes for to 1 against. TheBritish Government and Workers' members voted for the Convention; theBritish Employers' representative abstained.18. The Convention on the Right of Association and the Settlement ofLabour Disputes seeks to protect the rights of employers and employed to associate for lawful purposes, and in particular the right of trade unions to conclude collective agreements with employers' organisations. It also pro-poses that conciliation machinery for the rapid settlement of industrial disputes should be encouraged.19. In the Plenary Session of the Conference on the text of this Conven-tion, Mr. Ward (Government delegate, Australia) proposed the insertion of aprovision that " no worker shall be prejudiced in his employment or. dis-criminated against in any way or be dismissed from his employment because he is a member or agent or official of a trade union." While .there was complete unanimity as to the principle embodied in this proposed amend-ment the principle of the right to organise many delegates felt that, asthe expression of the principle raised complicated issues which were being dealt with comprehensively by the Conference in its examination of the general question of Freedom of Association and Trade Union Rights and as it was expected that a generally acceptable text which would be applicableuniversally would be adopted in 1948, it would be preferable not to attemptto deal with the question piecemeal in a Convention confined to Non-Metropolitan Territories. Accordingly the amendment failed to win sufficient support to secure its adoption.20. The Convention was finally adopted by 121 votes for to 0 against. TheBritish Government, Employers' and Workers' representatives all voted forthe Convention.21. The provisions of the Convention on Labour Inspectorates in Non-Metropolitan Territories relate to the status, duties and rights of such labourinspectorates. The Convention was adopted by 120 votes for to 0 against.The British Government, Employers' and Workers' representatives all voted for the Convention.22. The Convention on the Application of International Labour Standardsto Non-Metropolitan Territories provides for the application of certain Inter-national Labour Conventions to non-metropolitan territories for whichMember States have responsibility in such matters. The Conventions inquestion form an annex to the Convention. This Instrument represents a new departure in International Labour Organisation practice since the Conven-tions may in certain cases be ones which have not been ratified on behalf of the metropolitan territory concerned; the form of the Convention never-theless enables consideration to be given by the State Member concerned tothe extent to which such Conventions may be applied to the non-metro-politan territories for which that Member is -responsible. This is animportant innovation, the results of which will be watched with interest.23. The Convention was adopted by 95 votes for to 20 votes against. TheBritish Government and Workers' representatives voted for the Convention;the British Employers' representative voted against. j!24. The Convention on Maximum Length of Contracts provides for thVregulation by agreements of the maximum periods of service for singleworkers and for workers accompanied by their families. The Convention wasadopted by 99 votes for to 0 against. The British Government and Workers'representatives voted for the Convention; the Employers' representativeabstained.ORGANISATION OF LABOUR INSPECTION IN INDUSTRIAL and commercial UNDERTAKINGS(Item IV of the Agenda)25. Mr. G. R. A. Buckland (Government representative, United Kingdom)was elected Reporter of the Conference Committee set up to consider the subjects covered by Item IV of the Agenda. In presenting his report to theConference Mr. Buckland said that the Committee had considered " in great detail how far and precisely in what terms the widely accepted principles for the organisation of labour inspection could appropriately be embodied in the binding legal instrument of a Convention at the present stage." he explained that the Convention proposed by the Committee was not intendedto be the final step in this very important matter, but that it would be agreat step forward.26. The Convention as finally adopted the Labour Inspection Conven-tion, 1947 makes provision for the organisation of systems of labourinspection under the control of a central authority, so far as is compatible with the administrative practice of the Member, to be undertaken by a staffof public officials composed of suitably qualified and trained inspectors, eithermen or women. Their main functions should be to secure enforcement of thelaw and to supply technical information and advice to employers and workers,and in that connexion they should be empowered to take steps with a viewto the remedying of defects which may threaten the health or safety ofworkers and should be notified of industrial accidents and occupationaldiseases, in accordance with national laws or regulations. The Conventiondeals with labour inspection in commercial as well as industrial workplaces.27. The Convention was adopted by 135 votes for to 0 against. The BritishGovernment, Employers' and Workers' representatives all voted for theConvention.28. The Conference also adopted two Recommendations on the subject oflabour inspection. One Recommendation supplements the Labour Inspec-tion Convention, 1947, and deals" with the preventive duties of labourinspectorates in regard to new industrial or commercial establishments, withthe collaboration of employers and workpeople in regard to health and safety,and with details as to the information to be included in published annual reports on the work of inspection services; it also includes a recommendation that the functions of labour inspectors should not include that of acting as conciliator or arbitrator in proceedings concerning labour disputes. The otherRecommendation relates to the application to mining and transport under-takings of appropriate systems of labour inspection.29. Both the Recommendations were adopted by 135 votes for to 0 against.The British Government, Employers' and Workers' representatives voted for both Recommendations.30. In addition, a resolution was adopted urging Governments to applyto all workers employed in industrial and commercial undertakings the legal provisions for the protection of workers which are enforceable by labourinspectors.EMPLOYMENT SERVICE ORGANISATION(Item V op the Agenda)31. The Conference had a first discussion on the question of employment service Organisation and decided the principles which should be embodied in a Convention and Recommendation to be adopted at the next Sessionof the Conference. These include the need to integrate the employment service of a country within its economic programme as a whole and to achievean effective employment service through the active co-operation of employers'and workers' organisations. On the latter point the United KingdomGovernment member of the Conference Committee on this subject suggestedspecific mention of advisory Committees as the means through whichmanagement-labour co-operation should be achieved. It is also proposedthat the Recommendation should include provisions regarding the work of specialised employment services in facilitating the mobility of labour.REPORTS ON THE APPLICATION OF CONVENTIONS(Item VI of the Agenda)32. In its report to the Conference, the Committee set up to consider thequestion of the application of Conventions stressed the importance to beattached to this subject. It was agreed that the present machinery of super-vision does not as yet possess all the effectiveness required and suggestions were made for improvement, particularly with reference to the arrangementsfor the work of the Committee of Experts.FREEDOM OF ASSOCIATION AND INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS(Item VII of the Agenda)33. This item was placed on the Agenda at the request of the Economicand Social Council, to which memoranda and resolutions on the subject had been submitted by the World Federation of Trade Unions and theAmerican Federation of Labour.34. The Conference Committee set up to consider this subject included44 Government Members and thus included representatives of thevery great majority of the Governments attending the Conference. It also included 22 Employers' members and 22 Workers' members as well as aconsiderable number of substitute members.35. The Committee devoted a considerable time to a discussion of theform which it should recommend the "decisions of the Conference should take.On the proposal of the United Kingdom Government representative theCommittee decided to adopt the following approach to its task: first to try to reach agreement on certain basic principles, then to decide whether RESOLUTIONS39. In a resolution submitted by Mr. Leon Jouhaux (French workers'delegate) the Conference affirmed "its readiness, within the scope of its.functions, to make its full contribution and that of the forces which it represents, to the great work of world reconstruction '' signified by the meetings taking place in Pajis to examine means of speedy reconstruction in Europe, as suggested by the United States Secretary of State Marshall.40. Three further z-esolutions were adopted by the Conference. One on welfare facilities for workers, submitted by the Belgian Government delegate,referred especially to the importance of such services as canteens, rest and recreation facilities, sanitary and medical facilities, travel arrangements toand from work and accommodation for workers employed away from home.Another resolution, submitted by the Polish Government delegate, concerned the maintenance of the rights of migrant workers under social insurance schemes, already the subject of Convention No. 48 adopted at an earlierSession of the Conference. The resolution requested the Governing Body totake certain steps to ascertain the difficulties impeding the ratification of thethose principles should be embodied in a formal Resolution or in a report orin a combination of a Resolution and a report, and finally to consider whether any of the agreed principles should be put into the form of a Convention orConventions and if so which should be recommended for inclusion inConventions in 1948 and which in subsequent years. This method of approach is reflected in the action subsequently taken by the Conference, onthe Committee's recommendation.36. The Committee also considered the -question of international machinery for supervising freedom of association. The World Federate J.of Trade Unions had suggested the establishment of a Committee for trade Union Rights with the task of exercising permanent international supervision in regard to the maintenance, of trade union rights. Thissuggestion raised a number of difficulties and after a long exchange of viewsthe Committee unanimously adopted a Resolution submitted by the UnitedKingdom Government member inviting the Governing Body of the Inter-national Labour Office to consider the question of the establishment ofinternational machinery for safeguarding freedom of association in all its aspects and to report to the Conference at its Thirty-first Session in 1948.This Resolution was adopted unanimously by the Conference.37. The Conference also recorded unanimously decisions on a furtherseries of measures, based on the Committee's recommendations. Thus theConference passed a Resolution laying down a number of principles in regardto Freedom of Association and the Right to Organise and to BargainCollectively. It decided to proceed in 1948 to the consideration of a Conven-tion covering the principles dealt with in the Resolution but excluding certain-aspects of their detailed application. It further decided to put on theConference Agenda for first discussion at the 1948 Session, with a view to theadoption of one or more Conventions in subsequent Sessions, the following matters : (i) application of the principles of the right to organise and bargaincollectively; (ii) collective, agreements; (iii) conciliation and arbitration;(iv) co-operation between public authorities and employers' and workers'organisations.38. In so far as these decisions involved the placing of items on the agenda of the next (1948) General Session of the Conference they were embodied in a Resolution which was the subject of a record vote. The resolution was carried by 124 votes for to 0 against. The British Government,Employers' and Workers' representatives all voted for the Resolution. STANDING ORDERSi41. The Conference had before it a number of proposals for the amendmentits Standing Orders. The Conference adopted certain of these proposals,including amendments relating to the scope of the Committee on theApplication of Conventions, the disqualification of Members in arrears inthe payment of their contributions to the Organisation, and the procedure for voting on reports of the Credentials Committee at plenary sessions ofthe Conference. Other proposals were remitted for further consideration at a later date.REPRESENTATIVE OF NON-MEMBER STATE42. A representative from the Government of El Salvador attended theConference.REPRESENTATIVES OF OTHER ORGANISATIONS43. The following international organisations were represented at theConference: the United Nations, the United Nations Educational, scientific and Cultural Organisation, the International Monetary Fund and the interim commission of the World Health Organisation.TEXTS44. The texts of the Conventions and Recommendations adopted by theConference are given in Appendix II. The texts of the Resolutions are givenin Appendix III.We have the honour to be, Sir,Your obedient Servants,(Signed) G. MYRDDIN-EVANS,G. R. A. BUCKLAND.Convention. The third of these resolutions, submitted by the United StatesGovernment delegate, summarised, with the object of bringing them to theattention of States Members of the Organisation, the measures taken by theInternational Labour Conference in the field of women's work. APPENDIX II. Texts op the Conventions and Recommendations adopted by the ConferenceINTERNATIONAL LABOUR conference convention (No. 81) concerning Labour Inspection in Industry and CommerceThe General Conference of the International Labour Organisation,Having been convened at Geneva by the Governing Body of the InternationalLabour Office, and having met in its Thirtieth Session on 19 June 1947, andHaving decided upon the adoption of certain proposals with regard to theorganisation of labour inspection in industry and commerce, which is thefourth item on the agenda of the session, andHaving determined that these proposals shall take the form of an international convention,adopts this eleventh day of July of the year one thousand nine hundred and forty-seven the following Convention, which may be cited as the Labour InspectionConvention, 1947:Part I. Labour Inspection in IndustryArticle each Member of the International Organisation for which this convention is in force shall maintain a system of labour inspection in industrial workplaces.Article 21. The system of labour inspection in industrial workplaces shall apply to allworkplaces in respect of which legal provisions relating to conditions of work andthe protection of workers while engaged in their work are enforceable by labourinspectors.2. National laws or regulations may exempt mining and transport undertakings or parts of such undertakings from the application of this Convention.Article 31.
